Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Creating High-Completion CS Online Learning Using Educational Psychology Principles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Integrating computer science into the high school curriculum can enhance the preparation of students interested in a broad range of careers. To accomplish this goal, it is essential that high school teachers be well prepared to teach their students and have effective tools and resources available for instruction. In this project the collaborative team, from Georgia Tech and Luther College, will adapt their existing Computer Science Principles eBook for high school teachers to become a general purpose Computer Science Principles (CSP) eBook for students. They will compare the usability of the eBook on the different populations and compare learning outcomes of students who learn at a distance to those who use the eBook in a face to face environment. Their general research question is: What can be learned about CS in a low-cognitive load, principles-based eBook format? The long term impact of this work is to create a new model for online learning that helps adults complete computer science learning and also helps traditional students.

The ebook incorporates findings from educational psychology such as worked examples, multiple modality presentations, low cognitive load exercises, social supports from small group activities, and frequent testing interleaved with examples. The eBook utilizes contextualized approaches which have been successful in engaging and retaining female and under-represented minority students. The project team will conduct two studies: Study #1: CSP face-to-face class vs eBook: The project team will provide the CSP eBook to a face-to-face CSP class (both high school and undergraduate) and to a set of students interested in studying CSP on-line (most likely in rural Georgia). They will compare these students for learning outcomes. They are also interested in the drop-off in use of features within the book. When students stop engaging in the on-line materials, is that because of the materials, or is it because of the on-line course delivery mechanism? Study #2: Teachers vs Students: The project team is creating two eBooks for CSP content, one for teachers and one for students. By comparing these populations, they can develop a better understanding of how non-traditional and traditional students use e-books differently. They will do comparisons based on content knowledge (using a new validated measure they will develop as part of the project) and usability (do teachers and students use different features, or at different rates?). They will also use interviews and surveys to understand differences in motivations to use and complete the eBook.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have developed a new model for online learning organized around a dynamic, web-based book (ebook), informed by principles of educational psychology. Adults today know how to manage books, fitting in reading in whatever time they have available and eventually getting to the end. Our hypothesis is that ebooks will be a high-completion online education model. We built three ebooks in this project:

  • An ebook to teach the AP CS Principles (CSP) big ideas to high school students.
  • An ebook for AP CSP high school teachers, with the same content plus solution and pedagogical content knowledge, such as how to teach concepts and common student misconceptions. 
  • An ebook to support students reviewing for the AP Computer Science Level A examination (in Java).

Our ebook for the AP CS Principles (CSP) course incorporates findings from educational psychology extensively: worked examples, multiple modality presentations, low cognitive load exercises, social supports for small group activities, and frequent testing opportunities interleaved with examples. We call our model Examples+Practice. Our examples are contextualized which means that the computer science is taught in terms of student-centric problems and application areas, from image manipulation to driving around a robot “turtle.” Contextualized computing education is an approach which we have shown to be successful in engaging and retaining a diverse range of students. 

The original purpose for our ebook project was to prepare high school CS teachers. We have too few computer science teachers to meet the demand for CS education in high schools in the United States. In general, there is enormous demand for more computer science learning, with the undergraduate enrollment explosion as evidence. Our group has published field studies in the past showing shown that graphic designers, high school teachers, and other working professionals are interested in learning computer science. One way that working adults (like high school teachers) learn about computer science is to sign up for MOOCs (Massive On-line Open Class) on CS topics. However, research studies have also shown that few students from teacher populations will actually complete a MOOC. Instead, the completer for MOOCs tends to be young and well-educated (often having studied the subject before). We need alternative to MOOCs to train as many new CS teachers as we need. We started our ebooks to meet that need. 

After we built both student and teacher ebooks, we conducted a series of studies.

  • We published the first design-based research study in the International Computing Education Research community on how we iteratively developed our ebooks to improve teacher success. Our paper presented empirically-supported design guidelines for ebooks.
  • We published a study comparing teacher and student use of the ebook. The underlying research question was: “Did we have to have two ebooks, or can students and teachers just learn from the same materials?” We showed that high school students and teachers use the ebooks differently. Teachers are successful, reflective learners. They don’t let themselves get stuck — they give up on a problem if they’re not getting it. Students will persist at a problem for ten times longer, and still not get it. Students make irrational moves in the ebook, like running a program, then running it again (without change) as they expect the program to run differently the second time. Overall, students need more metacognitive supports (e.g., hints and guidance), while teachers need more navigation supports so that they can zoom in on exactly what they need.

We had a broader impact in the way that did the ebook project. We made a significant effort to develop assessments and evidence to support our design decisions. 

  • We built (and released to the community) a validated, multi-lingual assessment of CS1 knowledge, the SCS1. There were three papers at the SIGCSE 2019 Symposium built upon the SCS1.
  • Two PhD dissertations were funded by this work: Briana Morrison who showed the value of Parsons problems and subgoal labeling, and Barbara Ericson who invented adaptive Parsons problems and provided evidence that they can be even more efficient for CS learning than writing or debugging code.

In our work, we created and evaluated ebooks aimed at meeting a broad need for CS education in the United States. We produced research results showing how to make effective ebooks. We also produced instruments and ran laboratory experiments that demonstrated the value of the components of the ebook. These instruments and components are already appearing in others’ research, which broadens our impact beyond just our ebooks.
